Preparation and evaluation of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst for methyl formate synthesis from syngas Haijun Zhao a b Minggui Lin a Kegong Fang a ⁎ Juan Zhou a Yuhan Sun c ⁎⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China c Key Laboratory of Low-carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 201203, China Key Laboratory of Low-carbon Conversion Science and Engineering Shanghai Advanced Research Institute Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201203 China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts were prepared by mechanical mixing, sol-gel and impregnation methods. The phase structure, surface morphology and the chemical states of catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM and XPS. The basic property and reducibility of catalysts were investigated by CO2-TPD and H2-TPR techniques. Several types of basic sites with different basicity could be observed on the surface of catalysts. The sample prepared by impregnation method has the lowest reducibility, and the sample prepared by sol-gel method shows the highest reducibility. The catalytic performance was evaluated for the direct synthesis of methyl formate from syngas in a slurry phase. The catalyst prepared by mechanical mixing method shows the highest CO conversion of 14.2% and methyl formate selectivity of 83.4% among these catalysts, which could be attributed to the large amounts of strong basic sites and low reducibility of the catalyst. Keywords Cu-Mn mixed oxides CaO-ZrO2 Methyl formate Mechanical mixing Sol-gel Impregnation 1 Introduction As one of the most important intermediates of C1 chemistry, methyl formate can be widely used to produce chemicals such as ethylene glycol, N, N dimethyl formamide (DMF), methyl glycolate, acetic acid, methyl propionate, formaide and so forth. Therefore, the synthesis of methyl formate has aroused enormous interests and attention in the past decades. Nowadays, many synthesis routes have been established, such as esterification of methanol and formic acid, homogeneous hydrogenation of CO2 in methanol [1,2], dimerization of formaldehyde [3,4], carbonylation of methanol [5,6] and dehydrogenation of methanol [7,8], and the last two methods are now the general routes to synthesize MF commercially. The catalysts used in methanol carbonylation process for methyl formate synthesis are alkali metal methoxide (NaOCH3, KOCH3) or organic strong base (DBU, DBN) [9], while these catalysts facilely react with a trace amount of CO2 or H2O and it is very difficult to separate the catalysts from products. Recently, a great many new catalysts are developed to synthesize methyl formate via methanol carbonylation method. He et al. [10] prepared methyl formate by carbonylation method at low temperature in liquid over a soluble copper nano-cluster catalyst, and the CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity reached to 32.7% and 100%. Iwase et al. [11] studied the carbonylation reaction of methanol to methyl formate on CH3O- exchange resin and found this catalyst kept its initial activity after reusing four times, indicating an excellent stability. Vapor-phase dehydrogenation process of methanol to methyl formate often proceeds on Cu-based catalysts. Sato et al. [12] prepared CuAl2O4 spinel used in dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate in vapor-phase at 250°C, and Cu (II) species was found to be effective sites for the dehydrogenation of methanol at temperature above 250°C, whereas Cu (I) species in CuAlO2 was active for keeping high methyl formate selectivity up to 290°C. Other catalysts such as Cu-Cr, Cu-Mg, Cu-Si and Raney Cu catalysts were also used for the vapor-phase dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate [13]. In addition, the oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol to methyl formate is mainly carried out on V2O5-TiO2 catalysts [8,14,15] and some noble metal catalysts, such as Au, Ag, Pd and Ru [16–19]. 90.2% methanol conversion and 100% methyl formate selectivity were obtained over graphene-supported Au-Pd bimetallic nano-particles at 70°C by Wang et al. [20]. Besides the methods mentioned above, the process to directly synthesize methyl formate from syngas is also established, which is more economically effective and is a typical atom-economic reaction (2CO+2H2 →HCOOCH3). In this process, Cu-based catalysts play significant roles due to its well low-temperature catalytic activity and high methyl formate selectivity. To enhance the catalytic performance for the direct synthesis of methyl formate from syngas, homogeneous alkali metal promoters (NaOCH3, KOCH3) are indispensable in traditional Cu-based catalysts [21–23]. Nevertheless, they are sensitive to CO2 and H2O in system, resulting in the loss of activity [24–26]. Moreover, the promoters distributed on the surface of Cu-based catalyst could cause the blockage of the active sites [27]. Hence, in the present work, a novel heterogeneous Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst is designed for the first time to directly synthesize methyl formate from syngas in liquid without using alkali metal methoxide. The catalysts are prepared by the mechanical mixing, sol-gel and impregnation method, respectively, and the relationships between catalyst preparation methods, the structures and catalytic activity of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst are investigated. The aim of this case is to find an optimum preparation method of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst with the highest activity and methyl formate selectivity in direct synthesis of methyl formate and study the influences of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr properties on the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts 2.1.1 Mechanical mixing method The preparation of Cu-Mn mixed oxides is as follows: 1M Mn(NO3)2 (50wt.% in H2O, Alfa Aesar) aqueous solution with pH=3-4 was dropped into 1M copper ammonia solution of pH=9-10 with vigorous stirring at 35°C at a dropping rate of 1mlmin−1. After aging for 5h, the precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water twice at room temperature, dried at 110°C overnight, and calcined at 550°C for 4h. The obtained sample was coded as Cu-Mn mixed oxides. CaO-ZrO2 solid base was prepared by sol-gel method as the reported procedure previously [28]. Typically, 1g amphiphilic poly block copolymers (PEO20PPO70PEO20, Pluronic P123, Aldrich) and 1.53g Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (99%, Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 24.2ml absolute ethanol, which noted as solution A. Meanwhile, 4g zirconium n-propoxide (70wt.% in n-propanol, Alfa Aesar) and 0.43g acetylacetone (99%, Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 16.1ml absolute ethanol to produce solution B. Then solution B and 1.6ml H2O were dropped slowly into solution A. The resulting sol was aged at 60°C for 24h. After aging, the acquired white gel was refluxed in 0.5M NaOH solution for 24h. Subsequently, the sample was washed by deionized water to remove residual Na+, and then dried at 100°C overnight, calcined at 600°C for 6h to produce solid base. At last, Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst was prepared by mixing Cu-Mn mixed oxides and CaO-ZrO2 solid base at a mass ratio of approximate 3:1. Pellets were formed from the mixture above by applying 20MPa with a tablet machine for 1min, and then crushed into powder to obtain the catalyst, which is noted as MeM with the atom ratio of Cu:Mn:Zr:Ca=2.4:2.4:1:0.75. 2.1.2 Sol-gel method 1g amphiphilic poly block copolymers (PEO20PPO70PEO20, Pluronic P123, Aldrich), 5.0g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (98.0–102.0%, Alfa Aesar), 7.5g Mn(NO3)2 (50wt.% in H2O, Alfa Aesar) and 1.53g Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (99%, Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 24.2ml absolute ethanol, which was noted as solution A. Meanwhile, 4g zirconium n-propoxide (70wt.% in n-propanol, Alfa Aesar) and 0.43g acetylacetone (99%, Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 16.1ml absolute ethanol to produce solution B. Then solution B and 1.6ml H2O were dropped slowly into solution A sequentially and pH value of the mixed solution was adjusted to 5–6. The resulting solution was stirred for 2h before aging at 60°C for 24h. After aging process, the acquired gel was refluxed in 0.5M NH3·H2O solution for 24h. Subsequently, the product was filtered, dried at 100°C overnight and calcined at 550°C for 4h to produce Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst, which is denoted as Sol-gel, and the mole ratio is Cu:Mn:Zr:Ca=2.4:2.4:1:0.75. 2.1.3 Impregnation method Firstly, 1M Cu(NO3)2 (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 98.0-102.0%, Alfa Aesar) and Mn(NO3)2 (50wt.% in H2O, Alfa Aesar) solution were added to the CaO-ZrO2 solid base prepared in 2.1.1, and the mixture standed for 12h. Then the mixture was dried by an infrared lamp. At last, the as-prepared sample was calcined at 550°C for 4h. The obtained sample is Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst coded as IMP, and the mole ratio is Cu:Mn:Zr:Ca=2.4:2.4:1:0.75. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was conducted using a Bruker diffractometer employing Cu Kα radiation (40kV, 40mA, λ=0.154nm), a scan range of 2θ from 10° to 90° and a step size of 2° per min. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken with a JSM-7001F electron microscope operating at 10 or 5kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded by a JEM-2100F microscope with a field emission gun (FEG) and a point resolution of 0.19nm operated at 200kV. The specimen was prepared by ultrasonically dispersing the powder sample in ethanol for 30min and placing a droplet of the suspension on a copper grid covered with a carbon film. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) experiments were carried out with an AXIS ULTRA DLD X photoelectron spectrometry employing an Al-Kα (1486.7eV) X-ray source at 2×10−8 Pa. The binding energy of the samples was corrected with the energy of C1s (284.6eV) as the reference. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed in a flow system with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples (30mg) were packed into a quartz tube and heated in a 5vol.% H2/Ar reducing gas mixture at 30mlmin−1 from room temperature to 800°C by a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 and the detector signal was recorded continuously. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was used to determine the basic properties. The catalysts (0.2g) packed into a quartz tube were pretreated in a flow of He (99.99%) at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 700°C and kept at 700°C for 2h. Prior to adsorption of CO2 (99.99%) at 30°C, blank TPD was carried out from 30°C to 700°C to confirm no desorption of CO2 occurred. When the temperature elevated, the CO2 desorbed was detected by TCD. 2.3 Catalyst testing A batch stainless steel autoclave reactor with an inner volume of 100ml was employed. Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst (lower than 200mesh size) without pretreatment was added into the reactor, then the designed amount of methanol (99.95%, Alfa Aesar) and N, N dimethyl formamide (99.5%, DMF, Alfa Aesar) were poured into the reactor. After replacing the air in the reactor with N2 (99.99%, TaiYu Co, Ltd., China) for 2–3 times, feed gas (syngas, TaiYu Co, Ltd., China) was purged into the reaction system at room temperature until the pressure of the system was elevated to the required level. At last, the reaction temperature was increased to 160°C in 30min. The stirring speed was 1000rpm to resist mass transfer effect. The exhaust gases were analyzed using Carbosieve-packed column with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and Porapack-Q column with flame ionization detector (FID), and liquid samples were analyzed on Porapack-T column with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The composition of the feed gas was H2/CO with the molar ratio of 2/1, which was analyzed similarly to the exhaust gases. CO conversion and product selectivity were calculated as follows: X co ( % ) = ( N CO , in − N CO , out ) /N CO, in × 100 % S i = W i / ∑ W i × 100 % NCO,in is the molar number of CO in feed gas; NCO,out is the molar number of CO in exhaust gas; Wi is the mass of every product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD measurement The phase structures of catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 , and the results of corresponding peak intensity versus 2θ are listed in Table S1. The MeM and Sol-gel samples are mainly composed of CuO (Tenorite, PDF 48-1548) and incomplete spinel of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 (PDF 70-0262) with monoclinic and cubic phases, respectively. In IMP catalyst, Mn2O3 (PDF 73-1826) is formed besides CuO and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 phases with the weak diffraction peaks due to its low content or crystallinity. What is more, a weak and broad diffraction peak can be observed at nearly 2θ=30° in XRD patterns of all catalysts, which can be attributed to the diffraction of tetrahedral ZrO2 phase. However, no diffraction peaks of CaO are observed in all samples, suggesting that CaO exists in highly dispersed or amorphous structure. In addition, it can be found that MeM contains the phases of pure Cu-Mn mixed oxides (CuO and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4) and CaO-ZrO2 solid base in Fig. 1, illustrating that mechanical mixing does not change the structure of Cu-Mn and CaO-ZrO2 samples. The phase structures of the catalysts after reaction are also studied by XRD measurement in Fig. 2 . Cu and Mn oxides in MeM catalyst transform into Cu1.4Mn1.6O4 (PDF 71-1145), Cu (PDF 65-9026) and Mn(CO3) (Rhodochrosite, PDF 86-0173) after reaction, while only metallic Cu and Mn(CO3) are observed in used Sol-gel sample, indicating the deep reduction of Sol-gel sample during the reaction. As for IMP sample, Mn3O4 (PDF 24-0734) is found besides Cu1.4Mn1.6O4, Cu and Mn(CO3) phases. From the phase composition of the catalysts after reaction, we can conclude that Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts are more or less reduced by feed gas during the reaction, and the reduction degree is Sol-gel>MeM>IMP. Specifically, CuO and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 are reduced to metallic Cu, Cu1.4Mn1.6O4 and partial Mn(CO3) which may be formed from Mn2+ species and CO2 in system, for Mn2O3 in IMP sample, which is reduced to Mn3O4 and Mn2+ species after reaction. Three samples display different reduced species, indicating the discrepant reducibility of MeM, Sol-gel and IMP samples. 3.1.2 TEM and SEM results The general morphology and structure information are probed by TEM. Fig. 3 a–c display the HRTEM images of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts. We can see that three types of lattice planes are presented with interplanar spacings of 0.25, 0.29 and 0.48nm in Fig. 3a for MeM. The lattice spacing of 0.25nm can be assigned to (−111) plane of CuO, and the lattice spacings of 0.29 and 0.48nm are attributed to (220) and (111) planes of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4. As for the lattice spacings of 0.19nm and 0.25nm of Sol-gel catalyst in Fig. 3b, they are corresponding to (−202) and (−111) planes of CuO. In IMP sample (Fig. 3c), the 0.27nm lattice spacing can be ascribed to CuO (110) plane, the lattice spacings of 0.24nm and 0.29nm, pointing to (222) and (220) planes of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4. However, no lattice spacings belonging to Mn2O3 are found as observed in XRD pattern of IMP, which might be due to its low content in the sample. The lattice spacings mentioned above further indicate the presence of CuO and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 phases in MeM, Sol-gel and IMP catalysts. Fig. 3d–f show the TEM images of fresh MeM, Sol-gel and IMP catalysts. It can be seen that Cu-Mn mixed oxides aggregate together and form agglomerations with a particle size of 50–100nm in MeM sample (Fig. 3d). However, no nano-grains assigned to CaO-ZrO2 solid base are observed because of its low content compared to Cu-Mn mixed oxides in terms of volume. Two different sizes of particles are distinctly observed in Sol-gel sample (Fig. 3e). The one with a particle size of 10–50nm could be attributed to Cu-Mn oxides, another one with particle size about 5nm assigned to ZrO2 grains, and these two species of particles also aggregate together with low dispersion. The bulk particles are observed in IMP (Fig. 3f) with particle size of 0.2–1μm, whereas no CaO-ZrO2 nano-grains are found, for the CaO-ZrO2 nano-particles are covered by Cu-Mn oxides during preparation process with impregnation method. Fig. S1 displays the TEM images of used Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts. Some aggregate particles occur in Fig. S1a, however there are still many small particles with size of 50–100nm presented in used MeM, and the nano-grains of CaO-ZrO2 with size of ∼5nm are also observed. In used Sol-gel catalyst (Fig. S1b), the agglomerations of Cu-Mn mixed oxides and CaO-ZrO2 are formed. For the used IMP sample in Fig. S1c, the CaO-ZrO2 nano-grains with particle size of ∼5nm are of presence, indicating the separation of Cu-Mn sample from the surface of CaO-ZrO2 during the reaction. The surface morphology information of fresh samples is further characterized by SEM in Fig. 4 . MeM catalyst is composed of aggregates around 50–100nm (Fig. 4a). For the Sol-gel sample in Fig. 4b, the similar irregular aggregates with MeM are formed, while the particles seem to be smaller than MeM samples with a size less than 50nm. The morphology of IMP catalyst is different from the former two samples, and large flake-like appearance is observed with particle size of 0.2–1μm. The results of particle size observed in SEM are in line with those of TEM in Fig. 3d–f. The SEM images of used Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts are shown in Fig. S2. As can be seen, the particle size of used MeM and Sol-gel catalysts increase after reaction compared to fresh samples, and bulky particles with regular shape are observed in used MeM sample, which can be attributed to the metal Cu derived from the reduction of CuO during reaction. The morphology of IMP sample changes a lot from flake-like before reaction to irregular bulks after reaction. 3.1.3 XPS measurements The oxidation states of Cu and Mn in three different Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts are determined by XPS surface analysis. Cu 2p3/2 XP spectra of fresh MeM, Sol-gel and IMP are shown in Fig. 5 a. By deconvolution, three main peaks and two shake-up lines are observed in Cu 2p3/2 region of all catalysts. Topfer et al. [29] reported that the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 peaks is related to the chemical composition of the sample, especially the chemical environment of Cu cations, crystalline structure and the content of substituent ions. In MeM catalyst (Fig. 5a), the peaks at 933.7eV and 935.0eV can be assigned to CuB 2+ and CuA 2+ (A is tetrahedral sites and B is octahedral sites in spinel structure) [30]. The shake-up satellite peaks at 941.5eV and 943.9eV further indicate the presence of CuB 2+ and CuA 2+, because they do not occur on cuprous or metallic copper [31]. What is more, a redox equilibrium exists in Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 as follows: Cu2+ +Mn3+ =Cu+ +Mn4+ [32–34], so the peak at low binding energy of 930.9eV is assigned to Cu+ in tetrahedral sites. Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) is taken to further distinguish the chemical states between Cu, Cu+ and Cu2+ in Fig. 6 . According to the literatures [33,35], the Auger peak with kinetic energy of 918.5eV is assigned to Cu0, the peak at 917.6eV ascribed to Cu2+, for the peak at 916.5eV, which is related to Cu+. As can be shown in Fig. 6, the corresponding kinetic energy spectra display two peaks at 917.8±0.3 and 916.8±0.3eV, which could be assigned to Cu2+ and Cu+, respectively. Besides, a low kinetic energy broad peak at 913.0±0.3eV can be observed, which belongs to Cu2+ or Cu+ [36]. From the results above, we can confirm the presence of Cu2+ and Cu+ and the absence of Cu0 in Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst. The attributions of peaks in Sol-gel and IMP catalysts are similar to those of MeM. The XP spectra of Mn 2p for fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 5b, and five well-defined peaks can be obtained by deconvoluting the MeM, Sol-gel and IMP samples. As the Mn 2p3/2 binding energies of Mn3+ do not differ substantially from that of Mn4+, these two ions maybe coexist in the catalysts [37,38], and the difference of Mn cations at different sites of spinel structure cannot be observed by XPS analysis. In MeM sample (Fig. 5b), the peak at 641.1eV can be assigned to Mn2+, and Mn 2p3/2 satellite line at 648.1eV also confirms the presence of Mn2+, since Mn 2p3/2 shake-up features only appear in Mn2+ and those of Mn3+ or Mn4+ overlap with the region of Mn 2p1/2. Mn2+ species might exist in amorphous structure in MeM catalysts, because no diffraction peaks assigned to Mn2+ species are found in XRD patterns (Fig. 1). The existence of Cu2+ and Cu+ is confirmed by XPS of Cu 2p3/2 in Fig. 5a. Mn3+ and Mn4+ are also presented in samples according to the redox equilibrium: Cu2+ +Mn3+ =Cu+ +Mn4+. Thus the peak at 642.8eV can be assigned to Mn3+ or 4+ [37]. The similar results of peak attributions above can be obtained in Sol-gel and IMP samples, which indicate that three Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr samples have the same Cu and Mn oxidation states. The analysis of Cu 2p3/2 and Mn 2p3/2 for fresh catalysts is listed in Table 1 . As can be seen, the binding energy positions of peaks in Sol-gel sample are higher than those of MeM and IMP catalysts due to the strong interaction between Cu or Mn cations and ZrO2. In Cu1.5Mn1.5O4, the ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ is 1 according to the above redox equilibrium. However, the atom ratios of Cu+/Cu2+ in three catalysts are less than 1 and decrease as follows: MeM>Sol-gel>IMP, indicating the coexistence of CuO and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 phases and the decrease of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 content. Fig. S3 displays the XP spectra of Cu2p3/2 for used Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts. As shown, two main peaks at 933.4±0.1 and 934.6±0.1eV are observed, which can be attributed to CuB 2+ and CuA 2+, respectively. Nevertheless, no peak at ∼930.9eV assigned to Cu0 or Cu+ is found, indicating the absence of low valence state Cu cations in used catalysts, which is not consistent with the results of XRD for used catalysts in Fig. 2. The reason is that XPS characterization is a surface analysis method of element valence state, and the low valence state Cu cations are oxidized by oxygen in air during the catalyst treatment. The XP spectra of Mn 2p in used Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts are exhibited in Fig. S4. By deconvoluting Mn 2p3/2, two peaks are observed at 940.8±0.2 and 942.2±0.1eV, which could be assigned to Mn2+ and Mn3+ or 4+. For there are no Mn3+ or 4+ species in the used Sol-gel sample according to the results of XRD in Fig. 2, the Mn3+ or 4+ might also come from the oxidation of low valence state Mn ions on catalyst surface. 3.1.4 Temperature-programmed measurements Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was carried out to investigate the basic properties of catalysts. The CO2-TPD results of fresh MeM, Sol-gel and IMP are shown in Fig. 7 . Basic sites of the samples mainly exist on the surface of Zr4+ or Ca2+ species in Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts. Though it is hard to define a clear boundary between different desorption regions, the CO2 desorption profile of each sample can be divided into three regions, indicating three types of basic sites with a certain amount of basicity on the surface of samples. Region I from 50°C to 205°C is weak basic sites, region II in the temperature range of 205–475°C, corresponding to the moderately strong basic sites, and region III in the range of 475–650°C, which is attributed to the strong basic sites. Liu et al. [39] believed that the weak basic sites belong to the intrinsic basic sites of ZrO2, and the moderately strong basic sites could be ascribed to the presence of neighboring Zr4+ and Ca2+ affected the basic property of lattice oxygen on the surface [40], for strong basic sites, which is related to the Ca2+ on the surface of CaO-ZrO2 [39,40]. The basicity of different types of basic sites in MeM, Sol-gel and IMP catalysts is listed in Table 2 . We can see that the total basicity of three samples decreases as follows: Sol-gel>MeM>>IMP. However, MeM sample possesses a maximum amount of strong basic sites, illustrating that a great deal of Ca2+ ions exist on the surface of ZrO2, and the preparation method of mechanical mixing has no effect on those strong basic sites. In addition, the largest amounts of moderately strong basic sites are observed on the surface of Sol-gel catalyst with a small quantity of weak and strong basic sites (Fig. 7 and Table 2), which indicates that Ca2+ cations are highly dispersed in the sample prepared by sol-gel method. As for IMP catalyst, except for weak basic sites in the region of 50–205°C, both moderately strong basic site and strong basic sites are observed in region II and region III with very low basicity (Fig. 7 and Table 2), because most of basic sites on the surface of CaO-ZrO2 are covered by Cu and Mn oxides, hindering the adsorption of CO2 on the basic sites. Fig. 7 also exhibits the CO2-TPD of pure Cu-Mn mixed oxides and CaO-ZrO2. As can be seen, large amounts of strong basic sites are presented on CaO-ZrO2, and moderately strong basic sites are abundant on the surface of Cu-Mn mixed oxides, which correspond to the strong basic sites and moderately strong basic sites of MeM sample, respectively. The CO2-TPD profiles of used catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. The basic properties of MeM, Sol-gel and IMP change quite a lot before and after reaction. Weak basic sites increase on the surface of used MeM, Sol-gel and IMP samples compared to fresh catalysts, whereas strong basic sites and moderately strong basic sites decrease, illustrating that reaction has a detrimental effect on these two basic sites. Fig. 8 exhibits the H2-TPR results of the fresh MeM, Sol-gel and IMP catalysts. It has been reported that the Cu2+ in the spinel phase are relatively difficult to be reduced than the Cu2+ in CuO [41]. In MeM TPR profile, the peak at 216°C belongs to the reduction of fine CuO particles, the peak at 310°C corresponding to the reduction of Cu2+ →Cu+ in coarse CuO particles, for the peak at about 347°C, which is related to CuO/Cu+ →Cu0 in coarse CuO particles and the reduction of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 [31]. Similarly, three types of H2-consumption peaks are observed in Sol-gel TPR profile, and the attribution of the reduction peaks are in line with those of MeM samples. For the IMP TPR curve, two reduction peaks can be observed, and Mn2O3 phase exists in IMP sample according to the XRD results (Fig. 1). The first peak at 357°C is attributed to the reduction of CuO and the first step reduction of Mn2O3 →Mn3O4, while the second peak at 436°C is ascribed to the reduction of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 and Mn3O4 →MnO [42]. MnO cannot be reduced under the applied experimental conditions due to thermodynamic reasons [43]. Although different types of reduction peaks are observed in H2-TPR profiles for MeM, Sol-gel and IMP samples, basing on the results above, the overall reduction temperatures of samples increase with the following order: Sol-gel<MeM<IMP. That is to say, the reducibility of three catalysts is Sol-gel>MeM>IMP, which is in accordance with the XRD results after reaction in Fig. 2. The reducibility variation of three catalysts is contrary to the particle size of catalysts determined from TEM and SEM images (Figs. 3 and 4), indicating that particle size of samples has an important influence on the reducibility of catalyst, and small particles are more easily reduced than large ones [31]. 3.2 Catalytic activity and selectivity Table 3 shows the catalytic activity and product selectivity of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts in the direct synthesis of methyl formate from syngas in a slurry reactor. As can be seen, MeM sample has the highest CO conversion of 14.2% and methyl formate selectivity of 83.4%, as well as the highest space-time yield (STY) of methyl formate with 2.35gl−1 h−1. However, there is a decrease in the CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity of Sol-gel, namely about 10.2% and 79.8%, respectively. Additionally, Sol-gel catalyst shows the highest CO2 selectivity, which might be due to the deep reduction of the catalyst by CO during the reaction (Fig. 2). For IMP sample, the lowest CO conversion of 6.2% and methyl formate selectivity of 53.5% are obtained with the lowest methyl formate space-time yield of 0.67gl−1 h−1. A large amount of byproducts of HCHO and C2H5OH are also formed over IMP sample. According to the results above, we can conclude that the catalytic activity and methyl formate selectivity decrease in the order: MeM>Sol-gel>IMP. The order above is in agreement with the Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 content of three catalysts confirmed by XPS results in Table 1, indicating the presence of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 is beneficial to the methyl formate synthesis due to the strong interaction between Cu and Mn elements [33]. The relation of catalytic activity with XPS results is also studied. As shown in Fig. 9 , a linear relationship between Cu+/Cu2+ (in Table 1) and CO conversion is presented, which further proves the enhancement of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 to the synthesis of methyl formate. The mechanism of methyl formate synthesis from syngas has not been generally known. According to the previous literature [44], methyl formate is generated via the nucleophilic attack of a surface methoxy species on a formyl species or a formate species which can be formed from the adsorption of CO and H2 on the surface of Cu-based catalysts. The existence of basic sites on the surface of catalysts is in favor of the nucleophilic attack to generate methyl formate [45]. In this case, the Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts prepared by three methods possess different types of basic sites. MeM sample has the most of strong basic sites, and moderately strong basic sites are abundant on the surface of Sol-gel sample, while a spot of moderately strong basic site and strong basic sites are observed on IMP sample with the lowest CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity. Although Sol-gel sample has the maximum total basicity (Table 2), it shows the lower CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity than those of MeM sample. The highest catalytic activity and methyl formate selectivity are obtained on MeM, which can be explained by its enormous strong basic sites. Based on the results of catalytic activity, methyl formate selectivity and basic properties, it can be concluded that strong basic site is more beneficial to the catalytic activity and methyl formate selectivity than moderately strong basic site or weak basic site. MeM sample with maximum strong basic sites shows the highest CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity, and they increase with the number of strong basic sites on the catalysts. Since the catalysts are reduced during the reaction process (Fig. 2), the catalyst with higher reducibility is reduced easily by feed gas, leading to the bad stability or quick decay of catalytic activity. The reducibility of three Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts is strongly influenced by the particle size and phase structure of catalysts, and it decreases with the following order: Sol-gel>MeM>IMP. Thus the stability of catalysts increases with the order of Sol-gel<MeM<IMP. Though the IMP possesses the lowest reducibility, it shows the lowest CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity due to a small amount of basic sites. MeM sample shows the highest CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity due to the maximum strong basic sites and lower reducibility, and Sol-gel sample follows because of the largest amounts of moderately strong basic sites and highest reducibility among three samples. From the results above, we can conclude that the catalytic activity and methyl formate selectivity are strongly influenced by basic sites and reducibility of catalysts. 4 Conclusions Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts are prepared by mechanical mixing, sol-gel and impregnation methods and evaluated for the direct synthesis of methyl formate from syngas in liquid phase for the first time. The Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 incomplete spinel is formed in these catalysts, which is beneficial to the methyl formate synthesis. The reducibility is influenced by the particle size and phase structure of catalysts, and it decreases with the following order: Sol-gel>MeM>IMP. MeM sample possesses abundant strong basic sites, and Sol-gel sample has the maximum moderately strong basic sites. However, only a very small amount of moderately strong basic sites and strong basic sites are given on IMP catalyst. The highest CO conversion of 14.2% and methyl formate selectivity of 83.4% are obtained over MeM sample, and Sol-gel sample follows. IMP catalyst performs the lowest CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity. The CO conversion and methyl formate selectivity of three catalysts are strongly influenced by their basic sites, especially strong basic sites, and reducibility. The direct synthesis of methyl formate is an atom-economic reaction, and it should have great potential in the green and efficient route to synthesize methyl formate from syngas. coredata.dc:description: Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalysts were prepared by mechanical mixing, sol-gel and impregnation methods. The phase structure, surface morphology and the chemical states of catalysts were characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM and XPS. The basic property and reducibility of catalysts were investigated by CO2-TPD and H2-TPR techniques. Several types of basic sites with different basicity could be observed on the surface of catalysts. The sample prepared by impregnation method has the lowest reducibility, and the sample prepared by sol-gel method shows the highest reducibility. The catalytic performance was evaluated for the direct synthesis of methyl formate from syngas in a slurry phase. The catalyst prepared by mechanical mixing method shows the highest CO conversion of 14.2% and methyl formate selectivity of 83.4% among these catalysts, which could be attributed to the large amounts of strong basic sites and low reducibility of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation and evaluation of Cu-Mn/Ca-Zr catalyst for methyl formate synthesis from syngas
